body:
What would the "pointer" to the version be? If each thing tried to load the `/_app/version.json` file instead, presumably that would be different across different builds of the app as well, no?

The current behavior doesn't feel like a bug to me. If your hosting platform (for whatever reason) rebuilds the app when scaling horizontally, that sounds like a great reason to manually specify a version based on, say, the current Git SHA1.

I think my main gripe with it is that is so implicit that not setting a version leads to uniquely generated files. I completely agree with you on the solution, it is simply quite a challenge to come to that conclusion without doing quite a lot of digging.

edit: I've changed the wording of the issue a bit to allow for a more holistic approach

Perhaps if we didn't embed the version in the generated files, but instead included it in the rendered HTML...

```diff
<script type="module" data-sveltekit-hydrate="1vcz4c4">
  import { start } from "./_app/immutable/start-425c5ea9.js";

  start({
    env: {},
    hydrate: {
      status: 200,
      error: null,
      node_ids: [0, 3],
      params: {},
      routeId: "",
      data: (function(a){return [a,a]}(null)),
      form: null
    },
    paths: {"base":"","assets":""},
    target: document.querySelector('[data-sveltekit-hydrate="1vcz4c4"]').parentNode,
    trailing_slash: "never",
+   version: 'xyz123'	
  });
</script>
```

...then it wouldn't matter so much, since the assets themselves would retain the same hashes.
(Though I will say that creating separate builds when scaling horizontally seems like... an interesting design choice?)

I do think it would still be helpful to continue to have a URL that could easily be queried to find out the deployed version. I know `/_app/version.json` isn't part of the public API, but I've definitely used it on sites in production.

I have an app with an external authentication layer that lives completely outside the app, and I have `/_app/` URLs set to be accessible without logging in, and it's nice to be able to just query `/_app/version.json`. If that were replaced by what's being proposed above, I would need to sign in, get a server-rendered HTML page served to me, look at its source, and parse through for the `version:` portion, which is a lot less convenient. I imagine my situation (with the external authentication layer) is not particularly unusual.

@Rich-Harris more of an oversight and limitation in human resources at the time, and I fully agree its uhum "less than desirable", but I do think it helps to persist file names when file contents do not change, and in theory this is an undesired and implicit change in the file. I think not embedding it is the way to go here even in interestingly designed environments.

> If that were replaced by what's being proposed above, I would need to sign in, get a server-rendered HTML page served to me, look at its source, and parse through for the `version:` portion

Unless we were to expose it?

```js
import { version } from '$app/environment';
```
+1 on pulling the version out of the logic (js files). Having a query-able endpoint I can totally see the value of, but I also worry about an extra request if that's the only place to get it from.

issue.title: Make "version" available from $app/environment
issue.body:
### Describe the problem

Caching is great, it makes things fast. But using a cached page after an app deploy means all the script references are wrong and "bad things". So some form of "app version" needs to be part of any cache key.

There is a generated version string, used for the update checks. That could be read from `build/client/_app/version.json`except ... it won't be there during the build if pre-rendering.

So you have to check if running in `dev` or `prerendering` mode before reading the file.

### Describe the proposed solution

I would like to be able to access the version string from `$app/environment`

### Alternatives considered

Maybe it's already exposed from '$service-worker'?

But I don't know if that only works if using a service-worker, and it feels odd importing it from there when it isn't _really_ anything todo with a service-worker.

### Importance

nice to have

### Additional Information

_No response_

issue.title: don't hardcode `version` in client bundle
issue.body:
fixes #7144. #7689 makes this nice and easy

### Please don't delete this checklist! Before submitting the PR, please make sure you do the following:
- [x] It's really useful if your PR references an issue where it is discussed ahead of time. In many cases, features are absent for a reason. For large changes, please create an RFC: https://github.com/sveltejs/rfcs
- [x] This message body should clearly illustrate what problems it solves.
- [ ] Ideally, include a test that fails without this PR but passes with it.

### Tests
- [ ] Run the tests with `pnpm test` and lint the project with `pnpm lint` and `pnpm check`

### Changesets
- [x] If your PR makes a change that should be noted in one or more packages' changelogs, generate a changeset by running `pnpm changeset` and following the prompts. All changesets should be `patch` until SvelteKit 1.0
